fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • An obituary said that during the second world war the future Alaska senator Ted Stevens flew B-46 bombers over the "Hump" – the eastern end of the Himalayas – between India and China. That should have been C-46 transports. The article also said that "until oil was found in 1967 at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska was largely inhabited by native peoples". In fact, the flow of incomers had tipped the balance against the native inhabitants well before the 1960s (12 August, page 29). • We said that it was Wilfred who, in the Walter Scott novel Ivanhoe, split the arrow of an adversary (How Merrie England – and Disney – owe everything to an unloved Scot, 17 August, page 13). The credit for this manly feat at an archery competition should have gone to Robin of Locksley, aka Robin Hood. • The Conservatives lost power in 1997 and not, as a slip in our digits made out, in 1979 (Political briefing: Time for Labour to be robust opposition, 19 August, page 7). • Hard by homophone corner: "This can happen on mass. You can find whole graveyards with 20 or 30 ants in a square metre" ('Zombie' ants controlled by parasitic fungus for 48m years, 18 August, page 11). • An article recalling a European tour of teenage award-winning writers said that in 1980, "even the Sony Walkman was years away from being invented". The device was launched in Japan the year before (We drank, we smoked, we snogged, 18 August, page 12, G2).
